questions.text:
A 65-year-old diabetic male presented to the hospital complaining of chronic abdominal discomfort and unexplained weight loss over the past few months. A palpable firm mass was detected on the left upper quadrant upon physical examination. Ultrasound revealed a large mass in the left upper pole of the kidney. Due to suspicion of renal malignancy, the patient underwent a left nephrectomy. Based on the specimen obtained, what is the most likely diagnosis?


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Renal oncocytoma

 

Explanation:

 

Renal Oncocytoma:

  • It is most commonly seen in > 50-year-old adults.
  • It arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts.
  • Gross appearance:Tan or mahogany brown, with a central scar.
  • Microscopy: Composed of pink eosinophilic cells with small, round, benign-appearing nuclei.
  • Electron microscope: Numerous mitochondria (granular appearance)

     

 

 

Epithelioid angiomyolipoma (Option B) is a rare variant of angiomyolipoma composed of smooth muscle cells, fat, and blood vessels, and it often occurs in patients with tuberous sclerosis. However, the gross appearance of the specimen, without fat and showing a well-circumscribed mass, is more consistent with renal oncocytoma.

 

Clear cell carcinoma (Option C) would typically present with more aggressive features like hematuria, anemia, and vascular invasion. This patient's presentation along with a well-circumscribed mass is more typical of a benign tumor.

 

Urothelial carcinoma (Option D) is unlikely because the mass is located in the renal parenchyma, and in urothelial carcinoma it is typically found in the renal pelvis or ureter, often with associated hematuria.

questions.text: A child presents with hematuria and fever for the past 4 months. On examination, a mass-like structure was felt at the right flank. Which of the following features is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bilateral malar and mandibular hypoplasia

Explanation:

 

The given clinical vignette of a child with fever, hematuria, and abdominal mass in the right flank is suggestive of Wilm’s tumour or nephroblastoma. Bilateral malar and mandibular hypoplasia are characteristic of Treacher-Collins syndrome (not Wilms tumour).

 

Syndromes associated with Wilm’s tumour are :

Mutation

Syndrome

Features

WT1

WAGR syndrome
  • Wilms tumour.
  • Aniridia (absent iris) (Option B).
  • Genital anomalies (like cryptorchidism) (Option B).
  • Intellectual disability.

Denys-Drash syndrome
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudohermaphroditism) (Option A).
  • Early-onset nephropathy (leading to renal failure) (Option A).

WT2

Beckwith-Widemann syndrome
  • Organomegaly.
  • Macroglossia (Option D).
  • Hemihypertrophy.
  • Omphalocele.
  • Abnormal large cells in the adrenal cortex (adrenal cytomegaly) (Option D).

questions.text: A renal biopsy specimen has to be examined under microscopy for the presence of nephroblastoma. Presence of which of the following findings is less likely suggestive of the same?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Neuropils

 

Explanation:

 

Neuropils are eosinophilic fibrillary material surrounded by concentric groups of tumour cells (Homer-Wright pseudorosettes) seen in the histopathological examination of neuroblastoma. They are not seen in Wilm’s tumour.

Characteristics

Wilms Tumor

Neuroblastoma

Location
  • Kidney
  • Most common abdominal tumor in childhood
  • Common site: adrenal medulla,
  • Also seen in abdomen, pelvis & neck.
  • Most common primary renal tumor in childhood.

Histological features
  • Blastemal: Small blue cells. (Option B ruled out)
  • Epithelial: Abortive tubules/glomeruli.
  • Stromal: Fibroblastic or myxoid. (Option D ruled out)
  • Small blue cells with neuroblasts,
  • neurofibrils (neuropils) (Option A), and mature ganglion cells
  • Pseudo-rosettes (arrangements of small, round neuroblastic cells around a central fibrillary core)
Histological image

 

 

Below are the other components that might also be found in histological features of Wilm’s tumour:

  • Squamous or mucinous epithelium.
  • Smooth muscle.
  • Adipose tissue (Option C ruled out).
  • Cartilage.
  • Osteoid.
  • Neurogenic tissue.

It is important to remember that around 5% of nephroblastoma is anaplastic, characterised by cells with large, hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei and abnormal mitoses. TP53 mutation is associated with anaplasia.

questions.text: A histopathological report of renal biopsy done on a child states, “tumour cells suggestive of nephroblastoma along with adjacent sclerotic rests”. What is the risk associated with the presence of such sclerotic rests?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Contralateral tumour

 

Explanation:

  • Nephrogenic rests are precursor or preneoplastic lesions of Wilms tumours, seen in the renal parenchyma adjacent to approximately.
  • Hence, It is important to document the presence of nephrogenic rests in the resected specimen because these patients are at an increased risk of developing Wilms tumours in the contralateral kidney and require frequent and regular surveillance for many years.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding renal cell carcinoma is false?

choices.text: Clear cell RCC is the most common type overall.
Papillary RCC is most commonly associated with dialysis patients.
Medullary RCC is commonly seen in sickle cell trait patients.
Papillary RCC has the best prognosis.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Papillary RCC has the best prognosis.

 

Explanation:

 

RCC subtype with the best prognosis is chromophobe RCC, which tends to grow slowly and is less likely to spread.

 

Renal cell carcinoma:

Age group
  • Most common in the 6th and 7th decades.

Male: Female ratio
  • 2:1

Site of origin
  • Proximal convoluted tubule.

Risk factors
  • Cigarette smoking (most important).
  • Obesity (particularly in women) and hypertension.
  • Unopposed estrogen therapy.
  • Exposure to asbestos, petroleum products, and heavy metals.
  • End-stage renal disease.
  • Chronic kidney disease.
  • Acquired cystic disease.
  • Tuberous sclerosis.

Classification
  • Sporadic: Most common type.
  • Hereditary: Autosomal dominant, young age affected.
    • Von-Hippel-Lindau syndrome.
    • Hereditary leiomyomatosis & renal cell cancer syndrome.
    • Hereditary papillary carcinoma.
    • Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome.
  • Histological classification:
    • Clear cell carcinoma (most common type) (Option A ruled out).
    • Papillary cell carcinoma (associated with dialysis patients) (Option B ruled out).
    • Chromophobe carcinoma (best prognosis) (Option D).
    • Bellini duct (collecting duct) carcinoma.
    • Xp11 translocation carcinoma.
    • Medullary carcinoma (seen in patients with sickle cell trait) (Option C ruled out).

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female died within a few months after being diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma. The autopsy revealed a yellowish, spherical neoplasm in one pole of the kidney. The tumour cells invaded the renal vein and inferior vena cava. Histopathology is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Clear cell RCC

 

Explanation:

The clinical scenario and the histopathology image is suggestive of Clear cell carcinoma

Clear cell carcinoma:

  • Gross:
    • The yellow colour results from the prominent lipid accumulations in tumour cells.
    • It has a characteristic tendency to invade the renal vein, which may grow as a solid column of cells that extends up the inferior vena cava, sometimes as far as the right side of the heart.
  • Histopathology:.
    • The tumour cells have cytoplasm containing glycogen and lipids.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman presents with intermittent flank pain and occasional gross hematuria. Laboratory tests show normal renal function. A renal biopsy of a mass lesion reveals a mixture of mature adipose tissue, thick-walled blood vessels, and bundles of smooth muscle cells. All are true regarding this condition except:



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: More prevalent in males than females

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It is more prevalent in males than females.

Explanation:

The history, findings and image point to a diagnosis of renal angiomyolipoma.

Renal angiomyolipoma:

  • Benign neoplasm consisting of vessels, smooth muscle, and fat originating from perivascular epithelioid cells (Option C).
  • It is most often detected incidentally and has a female preponderance (Option B ruled out).
  • They are present in 25% to 50% of patients with tuberous sclerosis (Option A).
  • It has a high susceptibility for bleeding (can present as loin pain) (Option D).

Histology: Circular blood vessels, muscles, and fat; perivascular epithelioid cells with dense eosinophilic cytoplasm and mitotic figures.

questions.text: Hobnail nuclei are seen in which type of renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Collecting duct carcinoma.

 

Explanation:

Hobnail nuclei are a characteristic feature of collecting duct carcinoma/ Bellini duct carcinoma.

Papillary renal cell carcinoma (Option B) comprises cuboidal or low columnar cells arranged in papillary formations. Psammoma bodies may be present.

 

Chromophobe renal carcinoma (Option C) is made up of pale eosinophilic cells, often with a perinuclear halo, known as Plant.

questions.text: On histological examination, which of the following types of renal cell carcinoma shows large cells with a plant-cell-like appearance with a perinuclear halo?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chromophobe RCC

 

Explanation:

 

Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma shows large cells having plant-cell-like appearance with a perinuclear halo. These are positive for Hale’s Colloidal iron.

The histological image of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma:

chromophobe renal cell carcinoma" data-author="Nephron" data-hash="804" data-license="CC BY-SA 3.0" data-source="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Eosinophilic_variant_of_chromophobe_renal_cell_carcinoma_--_high_mag.jpg" data-tags="January2025" height="337" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/t2QkyTZ2n4beZtN3lhqG1737087743.png" width="500" />

Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma can differentiated from oncocytoma and clear cell RCC as follows:

  • CK7 is diffusely positive in chromophobe RCC but it is negative in clear-cell RCC.
  • Oncocytoma does not show perinuclear halo whereas chromophobe RCC shows perinuclear halo.
  • Chromophobe RCC cannot be histologically graded because of its innate nuclear atypia.

questions.text: Multiple losses of entire chromosomes are seen in which type of Renal Cell Carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chromophobe

 

Explanation:

 

Subtypes of renal cell carcinoma:

Type of RCC

Causes

 Microscopy Features

Clear Cell RCC (Option B)

Associated with mutations in the VHL gene (von Hippel-Lindau syndrome)

Cells with clear cytoplasm due to the accumulation of glycogen and lipids

 

Papillary RCC (Option A)

Associated with-

  • MET gene mutations
  • Hereditary Leiomyomatosis RCC
  • Dialysis-related cystic disease
  • Loss of Y

Psammoma bodies may be present


 

Chromophobe RCC

Associated with Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome

Loss of multiple chromosomes (Option C) (hypodiploidy)
  • Cells with pale, eosinophilic cytoplasm, Perinuclear halos- Plant cells
  • Hale’s colloidal iron +ve

 

Collecting Duct (Bellini Duct) RCC

Associated with mutations in multiple genes, including SMARCB1

Hobnail cells seen.

Worst prognosis.

Medullary RCC

Strongly associated with sickle cell trait.

Poorly differentiated cells
